sec.title: Abstract
sec.p: Samples for isolation of dictyostelid cellular slime molds were obtained from 20 collecting sites at 18 localities in south central and southeastern Madagascar during May 2009 . At least thirty species of dictyostelids representing seven genera were recovered from 52 samples of soil/humus. This total included 17 species described as new to science, 13 species already known from various localities throughout the world, and four isolates that remain unidentified. Fourteen of the new species isolated from these samples are members of the whorl-branched, light-spored genus Heterostelium (formerly Polysphondylium ). The overall level of species richness of dictyostelids in Madagascar is greater than what is known for all of mainland Africa sampled to date. Levels of biodiversity in Madagascar were higher for mesic than for xeric vegetation types , and each of the newly described species of Heterostelium appeared to have a limited distribution among the localities sampled .

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The dictyostelids (Phylum Amoebozoa), also known as cellular slime molds or social amoebae, are a group of eukaryotic microorganisms commonly found in soils worldwide, where they are ecologically important as predators of soil bacteria ( ). Dictyostelids are particularly well known for eastern North America, western Europe, and portions of China ( ), where they have widely studied for several decades. Much of the remainder of the world is understudied. This is particularly true for most areas of the Southern Hemisphere, where the most noteworthy studies appear to be those carried out in New Zealand by , Australia by , southern South America by , and South Africa by . The first publication on the dictyostelids of Madagascar was by but was limited to the description of several new species with little ecological data.

Madagascar is the world’s fourth largest oceanic island and has a total area of 59,280 km 2 . Long part of the supercontinent of Gondwana, it separated along with Africa and India from the rest of Gondwana (South America, Australia , India , and Antarctica ) about 150 to 160 million years ago and then split off from India during the period of 84 to 91 million years ago ( ). Madagascar has remained geologically isolated since then ( , ). The island has an elliptical shape and much of it consists of a large central plateau that ranges in elevation from 800–1,800 m and has a cover of vegetation that consists largely of savannah-steppe. There are some highlands in the northern part of the island, and a lowland belt that is now mostly cultivated surrounds the interior plateau. Major eco-regions found in Madagascar include tropical broadleaf forest remnants on the eastern coast and east-facing slopes of the plateau, subhumid forests in the highlands above 2,000 m and gallery forests in ravines on the plateau, a transition to ericoid thickets in the south, abundant mature grasslands and shrublands, spiny thickets in the far south, dry deciduous forests in the southwest and some areas of semi-desert ( , Figs. 1–12 ). The true tropical rainforest remnants along the east coast have an annual monsoonal rainfall of up to 4,000 mm , but the remainder of the country is much drier. The driest and coolest season of the portion of Madagascar considered in the present study extends from May to October, with the period between September and October especially dry. The wettest and warmest season occurs during the period of November to April, with an annual rainfall of 1,400 mm at the capital of Antananarivo ( ).

Madagascar has numerous endemic plants and animals, and a recent update to the endemic flora reported that 84% of indigenous angiosperms are endemic to the island, underscoring the critical role of the island in retaining this genetic repository of the world’s flora ( ). Land degradation is a major problem on the island despite many initiatives to protect the unique key ecosystems present. These include establishing, augmenting, and managing protected areas ( ) as well as finding methods to enrich and replant native tree species ( ).

The primary objectives of the study reported in this paper were to describe the distribution and ecology of dictyostelids on Madagascar , an island characterized by one of the most unique biotas of the world, and to compare and contrast the assemblage of species present (especially members of the genus Heterostelium ) with those reported from other regions of the world.

sec.title: Material and methods
sec.p: Fifty-four samples of soil/humus were obtained from Madagascar during a three-week period in May 2009 , which coincided with the end of the rainy season. These 54 samples came from 20 collecting sites in 18 separate localities ( Fig. 13 ) representing 12 different types of natural vegetation that included examples characterized by mesic or xeric moisture regimes ( Table 1 ). All samples were sent to two different coauthor laboratories for processing, with each laboratory receiving 27 replicate samples (half of the total 54). Isolation procedures for dictyostelids followed , with additional information relating to the culture techniques used described in . Later, all isolates were further reviewed by additional coauthors for morphological characterization.

Although 54 samples were collected and sent to the two laboratories, two of these samples were excluded from processing because they were very dry and consisted mostly of pebbles. Although 18 different localities were sampled, two of these (MGR-09-14 and MGR-09-29) encompassed examples of both a xeric site and a mesic site. As such, there were a total of 20 collecting sites in the 18 localities. The assemblage of species of dictyostelids now known from Madagascar was compared with those reported for mainland Africa, Australia , China , Costa Rica , Mexico , Tikal (in Guatemala ), and the United States ( , , Cavender et al. 2010, , ), where comparable sets of data are available (Table 3). For the purpose of this comparison, only isolates reliably referred to a particular species were considered, and all sub-specific identifications (e.g., varieties and subspecies) were excluded. For each region, data are provided for the total number of species, the number of species shared in common with Madagascar , the coefficient of community index for the pairwise combination of Madagascar and the region in question, and the percentage of the total number of species represented by members of the genus Heterostelium . The coefficient of community index used herein was CC = 2c/(a = b), where a = the total number of species in the first set of data being compared, b = the number of species in the second set of data being compared, and c = the number of species shared in common between the two sets of data ( ). Coefficient of community values range from 0 to 1.0, where 0 indicates no common species shared between two study areas or datasets and 1 indicates that all species are common to both study areas or sets of data.
Nomenclature used herein follows Sheikh et al. (2017) except for the five newly described species reported by .

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The 52 samples of soil/humus processed for dictyostelids yielded 34 species in seven genera. This total included 17 species described as new to science, 13 species already known from various localities throughout the world, and four isolates that remain unidentified to the level of species. Fourteen of the new species are members of the whorlbranched, light-spored genus Heterostelium (formerly Polysphondylium ) ( ). The 52 samples also yielded two new species in the genus Cavenderia and one in the genus Raperostelium . There is one additional new species ( H. migatissimum ) now known for Madagascar that was isolated from samples collected from a karst cave in the northern portion of the island in a separate study. This species is not included in Table 2 because it was considered outside the scope of the research being reported in the present paper..

The 52 samples were not equally productive for dictyostelids. No isolates were recovered from sixteen of the samples processed, but dictyostelids were recorded from 17 of the 18 localities. In only two instances did the number of clones recorded for a single collecting site exceed 100, and in only two others did the number of clones exceed 50. A total of 401 clones were recovered from the positive samples, for an average of 193 clones/gram for all samples ( Fig. 14 ). For dictyostelids, a clone is considered to be derived from a single propagule (spore or microcyst) and thus represents as much of an “individual” as possible to recognize for this group of microorganisms.

Altogether there were 12 xeric forest, shrub, and grassland collecting sites in eleven different localities. Samples from three of these localities did not yield any clones of dictyostelids at the time sampling was carried out. Three collecting sites in the same number of localities considered as mesic yielded only a single clone. The seven mesic localities included subhumid tropical, primary montane tropical and gallery forests bordering streams, and higher elevation grasslands. All samples except two obtained from subhumid tropical forest collecting sites had dictyostelids. These data suggest that populations of dictyostelids at a particular collecting site tend to reflect environmental conditions, with both overall abundance and species richness higher for vegetation types associated with mesic collecting sites as opposed to those associated with xeric collecting sites ( Fig. 14 ).

Xeric sites had more clones of the larger species of dictyostelids (e.g., Dictyostelium purpureum , D. giganteum , and Polysphondylium violaceum ) as well as the new species of Heterostelium . In contrast, mesic sites had more of the smaller species of dictyostelids (e.g., Cavenderia deminutivum , Hagiwaraea lavandulum , D. implicatum , and Coremiostelium polycephalum ) as well as the two newly described yellow-pigmented species Cavenderia canoesporum and C . basinodulosum ( Perrigo et al. 2020 ) . The predominantly grassy habitats yielded just two species ( Dictyostelium giganteum and D. leptosomum ).

Dictyostelium purpureum was the most widespread species and was recorded at seven collecting sites and in six different types of habitats. Dictyostelium giganteum was the only other species recorded from at least five collecting sites ( Fig. 15 ). The 14 new species of Heterostelium were found at 10 collecting sites and in seven different habitats, with nine from mesic collecting sites and six from xeric collecting sites. A single species was recorded from both mesic and xeric collecting sites.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The results obtained in the present study appear to provide additional information relating to the importance of environmental factors on the distribution of dictyostelids in nature. In Costa Rica ( ), the only samples which did not yield dictyostelids were either from high elevations or very xeric sites. In Mexico (Cavender et al. 2010), only samples collected from several desert sites did not produce dictyostelids. In Madagascar , with a much smaller number of samples, dictyostelid density in the processed samples was 193 clones/gram and 3.9 clones/isolation culture plate. This compares with 165 clones/gram for Costa Rica and 229/gram for Mexico .As already indicated, there were 30 described species plus four unidentified species isolated in the present study. This is a relatively high number, since there were 26 described species for all of Costa Rica and 28 for Mexico , which were sampled more extensively. The xeric and mesic sites in Madagascar had equal levels of species richness, with 17 and 18 species, respectively.

Despite the dry environmental conditions that prevail throughout most of Madagascar , species richness of dictyostelids was greater than all areas of the African mainland sampled to date. For example, there were 13 described species from tropical forests of the Central African Republic ( ), 10 from both Kenya and South Africa (Cavender et al. 2010), and a total of 25 for all of mainland Africa. In this initial sampling of Madagascar , there were 13 described species along with17 new, previously undescribed species.

Some of the species in the assemblage present in Madagascar appear are similar to those reported for the assemblages known from tropical forests in Mexico and Tikal, Guatemala . For example, Cavenderia deminutivum was first isolated from a seasonal rain forest near Veracruz , Mexico ( ) and has been reported several times since then, but only in Central America. This species occurred quite abundantly in the Ranomafana subhumid forest in Madagascar but has not yet been reported from elsewhere in Africa, although this does not preclude it being present. Also recorded were two species of yellow-pigmented dictyostelids reminiscent of the yellow-pigmented species C. granulophorum and C. medusoides from Tikal, Guatemala ( ).Another similarity with Central America was the presence in Madagascar of a species very similar to Heterostelium colligatum , a species first described from Tikal ( ).

Madagascar is characterized by one of the highest number of species (14) of Heterostelium of any region of the world sampled to date. This could well represent an example of radiation after several colonization events by one or two species. As Madagascar separated and drifted northward into a region of the world characterized by a more tropical climate, new environments related to different types of vegetation were created that were subsequently colonized by Heterostelium and the genus might have been selected for new morphologies under the new conditions. However, it should be noted that over recent geological time, the climate of Madagascar ( ), like the rest of the world, has undergone change. For example, Li et al. (2000) indicated that there is evidence to suggest that Madagascar has been subjected to catastrophic ecological and landscape transformation due to such factors as human activities and island-wide drought during the past 8,000 years. It is not known what impact this might have had on dictyostelids.

Interestingly, some similarities also have been noted for the myxomycetes, another entirely different group of eumycetozoans, from Madagascar and arid areas of Mexico ( ). It is possible that longdistance dispersal may have been a factor, since a recent study ( ) reported the occurrence in the Namib Desert of southern Africa of several species of myxomycetes previously known only from the New World. However, long-distance dispersal does not appear to be a factor for dictyostelids since their spores do not ordinarily become airborne ( ).

As indicated by the figures provided in Table 3, total numbers of species of dictyostelids reported to date ranged from 22 ( Australia ) to 46 ( United States ) and China (54). It seems likely that the highest numbers are related to differences in the sizes of the regions surveyed. For example, China is sixteen times the size of Madagascar . However, the total for Madagascar is higher than those of five other regions despite the fact that most of the data for the island were obtained from a single collecting trip. The number of species shared in common with Madagascar ranged from six to 11 with one noteworthy exception—Tikal. These totals are reflected in the coefficient of community values, which were fairly consistent (range 0.21 to 0.29), except for Tikal, which had a much lower value (0.07). Clearly, the assemblages of dictyostelids for Madagascar and Tikal vary rather considerably at the level of species.

The large number of species of Heterostelium recorded from Madagascar was noted earlier in this paper. Representatives of this genus made up almost half (48%) of all species recorded. Australia had the next highest total (32%). This could be linked to the fact that both Madagascar and Australia are isolated land masses characterized by a predominantly xeric climate. However, Tikal, with the next highest percentage of species of Heterostelium , has a mesic and not a xeric climate.

Although the present study was limited in extent, examining the data from just 52 samples from 20 different collecting sites in the central and southern part of the island, the results indicate that Madagascar has a species rich and distinct assemblage of dictyostelids, a pattern that is likewise observed in many other larger taxa such as plants and animals. Mainland Africa as a whole, based on the sampling carried out to date, appears to have one of the least biodiverse assemblages of dictyostelids of any continent, with the subcontinent of India also appearing to be characterized by a low level of biodiversity ( ). In contrast, Madagascar may have one of the most species rich assemblages of any region of comparable size anywhere in the world, based on the data currently available. There are some interesting correspondences between the dictyostelids of Central America and Madagascar that have not shown up in comparison with the rest of Africa. It is not immediately apparent why this occurs, even considering the breakup of Gondwana. However, the range of habitats available (at least those from which samples have been collected) may represent a factor. Of particular interest is the apparent speciation in the genus Heterostelium , which was found to occur prolifically in Madagascar .
